Context:
Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis
Code: S303
Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 5 semesters + 14 week Field Experience term (Unpaid)
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $10,463.00 *
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Health & Wellness
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Seven (7) week unpaid block begins in semester 6, and a fourteen (14) week unpaid block placement begins in the fall term of student's final year in the degree.
Program Availability: Open for domestic students in spring 2025
George Brown College has been offering training and education in Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA) for over 15 years and was the first college in Toronto to offer the Behavioural Science Technology advanced diploma and spearheaded the development of the Provincial Autism and Behavioural Science programs.

* The tuition fee is for domestic students only. International tuition fees may vary.

Context:
The college offers a fast-track degree program in Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which is open to students who have completed two years of a behavioural science technology advanced diploma program with a minimum GPA of 3.0 or graduated from a behavioural science technician diploma program with a minimum GPA of 3.0. The program includes a bridge semester during spring/summer (semester 4) before joining the third year (semester 5) of the four-year degree program.

ABA is an evidence-based practice used to treat and understand human behaviour, often applied to populations with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders. The ABA approach involves three components: a complete behavioural assessment, developing an effective plan based on assessment results, and ongoing evaluation of interventions.

The degree program includes a research component where students learn how to prepare an applied research proposal during semesters 5 and 6, with the actual research conducted during the fall semester of the fourth year. The Association for Behavior Analysis International has verified certain courses in this program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 3 Bridge) S303 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Association for Behavior Analysis International (ABAI) has verified the following courses toward the coursework requirements for the Board Certified Assistant Behaviour AnalystÂ® examination. The degree program at George Brown College prepares students to become practitioners and leaders in the field of behavior analysis. It offers a Honours Bachelors of Behaviour Analysis (S304) degree.

Graduates of any approved Ontario college behavioural science technology advanced diploma program with a GPA of 3.0 or higher are eligible to enter a bridging pathway leading to the fourth year (semester 7) of the Honours Bachelors of Behaviour Analysis degree program. External applicants from other institutions will be assessed for advanced standing on a case-by-case basis.

As of July 2024, the profession of applied behaviour analysis in Ontario will come under the jurisdiction of the newly expanded College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario.

Core courses focus on five areas of learning: behavioral science theories, principles and methods; special populations; psychology; research methods/statistics; and ethics, professionalism and leadership.

Contact Don Togade at Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca for more details or regarding advanced-entry options. The program is currently only available to domestic students, but current George Brown College International Students of C116 or C146 who wish to apply should also contact Don Togade.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 3 Bridge) S303 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* The field education options include participating in a block field placement in semester 6.
* Students will complete one 14-week unpaid field experience term between semesters 6 and 7, during which they are expected to conduct a research thesis.
* Prior to starting the field experience term, students will receive support from a field coordinator for exploring interests, preparing for interviews, and facilitating interview meetings.
* Students will receive support from an agency on-site supervisor and a college faculty field liaison once in their placement settings.
* ABA practitioners may have responsibilities such as assessment of clients' skills, development and implementation of skill acquisition programs, functional assessment of challenging behaviors, behavior management plans, data collection and analysis, case management, etc.
* Career options for ABA practitioners include Autism Spectrum Disorders consultant, ABA Therapist, Behavioural Support, Behaviour Technician, Behaviour Therapist, Behavioural Consultant, Behavioural Specialist, Instructor Therapist, Recreational Therapist, Residential Support Worker, Transition Co-ordinator, and Vocational Support Worker.
* Graduates of the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis fast-track degree program have gone on to earn a master's degree in related areas such as applied behaviour analysis, applied disability studies, counselling psychology at institutions like Brock University, The Chicago School of Professional Psychology, Missouri State University, Western University, and University of British Columbia.
* Graduates with an interest in working in long-term care facilities are encouraged to apply for the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) postgraduate certificate program.
* The S417 program is a two-semester online program where students will learn to coordinate and manage an interprofessional healthcare team of complex and long-term care.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 3 Bridge) S303 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The program offered by the college is a complex and long-term healthcare degree focused on coordinating and managing interprofessional healthcare teams, delivered on-demand for working professionals. It includes a clinical field placement component. The degree is broken down into eight semesters, with each semester having specific required courses:

Semester 4:
- BEHA 2106: Advanced Research Design and Statistics
- BEHA 2107: Advanced Assessment Strategies and Behaviour Theory
- BEHA 2111: Skill Acquisition: Advanced Theory and Application II
- BEHA 2112: Treating Challenging Behaviours II
- Liberal Studies Elective

Semester 5:
- BEHA 2103: Behavioural Approaches to Autism, Development Disabilities and Other Behavioural Issues
- BEHA 3001: Group Behaviour Therapy
- BEHA 3002: Behavioural Approaches to Acquired Brain Injury and Gerontology
- BEHA 3004: Psychometrics
- BEHA 3005: Standards of Practice in ABA
- Liberal Studies Elective

Semester 6:
- BEHA 3101: Clinical Behaviour Analysis
- BEHA 3102: Mediator Training: Applications to Parents and Staff
- BEHA 3109: Supervision Seminar II
- BEHA 3110: Block Placement II
- BEHA 4002: Behavioural Approaches to Health and Well-Being
- Liberal Studies Elective

Semester 7:
- BEHA 3103: Behavioural Approaches to Education
- BEHA 4001: Organizational Behaviour Management
- BEHA 4003: Service Delivery Systems and Interprofessional Practice
- Liberal Studies Elective

Semester 8:
- BEHA 4101: Consolidation of Behavioural Principles and Practice
- BEHA 4102: Advanced Topics in Behavioural Science
- BEHA 4103: Leadership in Behaviour Analysis
- BEHA 4104: Professional Standards and Practices in Dissemination
- BEHA 4105: Thesis (42 hours)
- Liberal Studies Elective

The graduate will have demonstrated the ability to learn about psychological theory, research and practices, design and conduct various assessments across a variety of settings and populations, and design and implement research-based programs.

The text provides information on the requirements and fees for a Behavioural Science Technology or related program at George Brown College. Here are the key factual details extracted from the text:

1. Various assessments conducted in different settings and populations.
2. Designing, implementing and evaluating research-based programs in Applied Behaviour Analysis.
3. Practising behavioural consulting skills with various populations.
4. Demonstrating professionalism and ethical standards in an interdisciplinary setting.
5. Communicating results orally and in written form.
6. Critically understanding, evaluating, and synthesizing social issues.
7. Tuition for Fall 2023: $10,463 (Domestic) + [Additional costs not mentioned]

9. Tuition for Fall 2024: [Not provided]

11. Admission requirements: successful completion of a Behavioural Science Technology advanced diploma program or equivalent with a minimum GPA of 3.0, OR successful completion of a two-year Behavioural Science Technician diploma program or equivalent with a minimum GPA of 3.0.

Context: Students in the program are required to have a Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed every year before entering into field or clinical placement. The process typically takes 2-3 months but can take up to 8 months. Students must ensure that their Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for working with vulnerable persons. The original copy of the Vulnersector check is required, and failure to provide a clear check may prevent students from starting their placement and completing the program. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, and more information can be obtained by contacting hwprograms@georgebrown.ca or 416-415-5000 ext. 2367. Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), and Behavioural Science Technician (C146). Students can book a campus tour on the website and sign up to receive application resources. The fees for the vulnerable sector check vary.
